Taxon name.Name: Aspergillus niger
Taxon name.Synonymy:
Current name: Aspergillus niger Tieghem 1867 MB#284309 
Taxonomic synonyms: 
   - Aspergillus foetidus Thom & Raper 1945 MB#284300 
   - Aspergillus aureus var. brevior Nakazawa, Simo & A. Watanabe 1936 MB#493810 
   - Aspergillus awamori var. fumeus Nakazawa, Simo & A. Watanabe 1936 MB#250920 
   - Aspergillus fuliginosus Peck 1873 MB#208679 
   - Aspergillus luchuensis Inui 1901 MB#151291 
   - Aspergillus cinnamomeus E. Schiemann 1912 MB#122195 
         - Aspergillus niger var. cinnamomeus (E. Schiemann) Thom & Raper 1945 MB#505077 
   - Aspergillus fuscus E. Schiemann 1912 MB#450741 
         - Aspergillus schiemanniae Thom 1916 MB#102113 
   - Aspergillus pyri W.H. English ? MB#453796 
   - Aspergillus niger var. altipes E. Schiemann 1912 MB#493817 
   - Sterigmatocystis nigra (Tieghem) Tieghem 1877 MB#231646 
   - Aspergillus lacticoffeatus Frisvad & Samson 2004 MB#500008 
   - Aspergillopsis nigra (Tieghem) Spegazzini 1911 MB#210007 
   - Rhopalocystis nigra (Tieghem) Grove 1911 MB#432029 
   - Aspergillus schiemanni Thom 1916 MB#252250

Nagoya protocol restrictions and complia: no known restrictions under the Nagoya protocol
Applications: trace element nutrition studies (Steinberg,1916-1941); fungus resistance testing of paper and paperboard (ASTM Std. D2020-76); of corrosion-resistant baking primer and water-based vinyl adhesive (Dev. Ind. Microbiol. 20: 25-39, 1979); of textiles (Brit. Std. BS 6085: 1981); of plastics (International Standard ISO 846-1978(E)) and other materials (Brit. Std. BS 2011: Part 2.1J: 1977); copper-resistant (ibid.); sterility testing (J. Pharm. Sc. 60: 1087-1088, 1971); production of citric acid (U.S. Pat. 4,040,906); sulfur bioassay (Bot. Gaz. 126: 120-123, 1965; Acta Pathol. Microbiol. Scand. 71: 333-338, 1967); degradation of apple distillery waste (Eur. J. Appl. Microbiol. Biotechnol. 17: 243-247, 1983) and starch in wastewater (Water Sci. Tecnol. 28: 267-274, 1993; J. Ferment. Bioeng. 79: 387-390, 1995); Production of carboxy-methyl cellulase, ß-glucosidase and xylanase from oil palm wastes (World J. Microbiol. Biotechnol. 8: 536-538, 1992) and extracellular lipases (IBID., 11: 669-667, 1995); leaching of aluminium from red mud (Environ. Sci. Technol. 28: 26-30, 1994)
